title: Ticket #6442: Be paranoid about CommitTransaction()'s implicit semantics
description: We changed the semantics of CommitTransaction() at some point from always dying on failure to occasionally returning negative numbers (and sometimes error stacks). It worries me that we haven't changed the code in a number of places to reflect this change. Initially, I propose to change the names of the calls to match their implicit semantics, and dprintf() warnings if any of the new functions -- which should behave identically to the original aside from this -- are used improperly. If that works for a while, it'd be nice to convert the checks to assertions. After discussion with TJ, he agreed that the dprintf()d warning should trigger test-suite failures.
remarks:
2017-Oct-11 15:00:30 by tlmiller:
It seemed prudent to this checked, even though it's going into the master branch, since CommitTransaction() is kind of important. TJ wanted a ticket, so here it is.

2017-Oct-11 21:20:51 by bbockelm:
Note that there's quite a bit of available help you can get from the compiler. See: https://gcc.gnu.org/onlinedocs/gcc-4.6.0/gcc/Function-Attributes.html

In particular, you can mark functions as:

  • noreturn: function doesn't return and should always call exit/abort . See https://github.com/htcondor/htcondor/blob/master/src/condor_includes/condor_header_features.h#L80
  • warn_unused_result: compiler should emit a warning if the function is called but the return value goes ignored.

2017-Oct-12 10:38:44 by tlmiller:
I'd forgotten about these two options, so thanks for the heads-up. However, I don't immediately see the utility of noreturn in this situation -- CommitTransaction() is in fact expected to return, just never with errors.

I'll look into warn_unused_result.

2017-Dec-13 11:43:30 by johnkn:
CODE_REVIEW changes look good.
